answers.answer: Ms. telanadw:Congratulation on your pregnancy and I hope you are feeling better since your last post.As for your sinus migraine, you can take acetaminophen (Tylenol) for pain relief. Please make sure you follow the over-the-counter dosing regimen and not to exceed the maximum daily dose of 4000 mg.Aspirin and NSAIDs (non-steroidal anti-inflammatory drugs) are best avoided during pregnancy. Using ibuprofen (Motrin, Advil) in the first two trimesters have not been show to increase risk of birth defects, but it needs to be avoided in the third trimester.It is important for you to follow your OBGYN with regular check-up. Consult your primary care provider and OBGYN and see if there are other underlying issues, such as seasonal allergies, sinus infection, gestational diabetes, etc.Often, headaches during pregnancy are due to hormone changes in the body. It is good practice to note your triggers, such as physical or emotional stress (due to lack of sleep or hormone changes) or hunger (since you are eating for two people now). Minimize triggers by getting enough rest and by eating healthy and on-time.Take good care of yourself by drinking plenty of fluids, taking prenatal vitamin (especially folate or folic acid), eating and sleeping well during your pregnancy. Prenatal yoga, meditation, and breathing exercises will also help relieve some of the pregnancy stress and tension.For additional information, please go to:1. Migraine Fact Sheet - Womenshealth.govhttp://www.womenshealth.gov/publications/our-publications/fact-sheet/migraine.cfm#d2. You're Pregnant: Now What? - Womenshealth.govhttp://www.womenshealth.gov/pregnancy/getting-ready/index.html3. Pregnancy and Medicines Fact Sheet - Womenshealth.govhttp://www.womenshealth.gov/publications/our-publications/fact-sheet/pregnancy-medicines.htmlv

question: Im 3 weeks pregnant. Anything i can use for sinus migraine. Its going on for 3 days now.
title: Sinus migraine
